values.alignmentText: Good in finance/consulting/enterprise (Dublin hub).
Generally good; occasional winter particulate spikes (solid‑fuel heating) in some areas.
Secularization advanced; Church influence diminished but present in schools.
Low; independent media/judiciary; EU member checks.
Opening accounts generally requires photo ID and proof of Irish address; a PPSN is helpful but not always mandatory. Retail banks plus fintechs support widespread contactless payments.
Scenic but cool-water beaches; swimmable mostly for cold‑tolerant; great walks year‑round.
Active scenes in cities; FLGS and clubs; cons like [Gaelcon](https://gaelcon.com) / [Warpcon](https://warpcon.ie).
Subsidies expanding (National Childcare Scheme); availability varies by city.
Good playgrounds, libraries, family‑friendly cafes; breastfeeding generally accepted.
National Childcare Scheme hourly subsidies; Child Benefit monthly; paid maternity benefit (PRSI-based), paternity and parents leave.
NCS available to legally resident families with PPSN; supports generally residency/PRSI-based; documentation and status checks apply.
Hiking, GAA sports, soccer, cycling, music, sea‑swimming.
Welcoming to newcomers; strong clubs/associations; expat communities in cities.
Track tax residency days; keep GNIB/IRP renewals current; maintain health insurance as required.
Housing/childcare expensive in Dublin; groceries/utilities moderate EU‑level—verify local indices.
Yes - dual nationality permitted; subject to other country rules.
Low unemployment; GDP volatile due to multinationals; high cost of living.
Open market economy with EU social protections.

English-language schools post strong PISA literacy/math scores, so the kids would get solid academics, but our preference for secular options means planning around Catholic patronage and oversubscribed urban schools.
Common for ICT roles via Critical Skills; reliable processes.
Generally high environmental quality outside dense urban cores; extensive protected landscapes and coastline.
Progressive bands; mid‑to‑high effective rates when including USC/PRSI—model scenarios.
Typical daytime 9-14 C (48-57 F); increasing rain/wind from October; daylight shortens steadily.
Safe cities; parks/playgrounds common; weather limits outdoor time some days.
Partner work authorization often available (e.g., Stamp 1G with CSEP spouse); confirm current policy.
26+ weeks maternity benefit (PRSI-based), paternity leave, about 9 weeks parents leave; child benefit; flexible work practices rising.
Supports for families; verify benefits by status and income.
Many supports tied to residence and PRSI contributions; some benefits require Habitual Residence Condition; check specific status.
Smart-casual with practical outerwear; midi dresses/knits, boots/sneakers; modest to contemporary looks.
Smart-casual layers and waterproof outerwear; clean sneakers/boots; understated tailoring for nights out.
Broadly flexible; safety relatively high.
Small but active ecosystem centred in Dublin and Galway; indie and services roles exist but AAA studios are limited—networking is important.
Visible in urban areas; acceptance growing.
Strong legal protections; parental leave improving; confirm details.
Increasingly egalitarian; traditional norms persist in pockets.
GNIB/IRP registration, PPSN, address proof; track tax residence days; private health cover early on; rights vary by stamp.
Rising precipitation and storm intensity; coastal flooding risk; less extreme heat than continental Europe.
Public system with long queues for some services; many carry private insurance.
Private insurance often required; access to public services depends on residency status—verify specifics.
Free Fees Initiative for eligible undergrads; SUSI grants based on income; wide HE options in Dublin/Cork/Galway/Limerick.
Non-EU often pay international fees; scholarships limited; pathways improve after longer residence or PR/EU status.
Family rentals remain scarce and expensive—three-bedroom Dublin homes regularly exceed €2k monthly—so we’d face landlord-favored bidding and compromises on space.
PAYE with USC and PRSI; yearly self‑assessment if needed; credits for couples.
Public primary/secondary largely free; many denominational schools; secular Educate Together network growing; voluntary contributions typical.
Residents with permission generally enrol without tuition; EAL support available; documentation and enrolment timing matter.
English dominant; Irish is co‑official; high English proficiency.
Broad legal protections; social acceptance high in cities.
Niche in discourse; mainstream politics centrist/center‑left/right mix.
Evolving; caregiving more normalized.
Active tech/game dev, parenting, LGBTQ+ groups; poly communities exist but low‑profile.
The €12.70 minimum wage is well-enforced, yet it trails the Living Wage (~€14) and can’t comfortably cover Dublin housing or childcare, so entry-level families feel squeezed.
Fast broadband in cities; widespread contactless; decent e‑gov; reliable grid.
Cliffs, peninsulas, lakelands, low mountains; many day/weekend trips.
Low seismic risk; Atlantic storms possible; robust building standards.
Abundant day trips by rail/bus/car from major cities.
Strong live music/pub culture; festivals year‑round.
Pub-centric socializing, live music, late bars/clubs in cities; generally safe; more family-friendly earlier in the evening.
[Imirt — Irish Game Makers](https://www.imirt.ie) (national association/network).
[Keywords Studios](https://www.keywordsstudios.com) (HQ Dublin), [Vela Games](https://velagames.com) (Dublin), [WarDucks](https://warducks.com) (AR/VR); plus indies.
Enterprise Ireland/LEO supports, New Frontiers, Imirt network; publishers/services in Dublin.
Dublin fast and pricey; Cork/Galway slower with trade‑offs on roles.
Balanced; extracurriculars common; independence encouraged; verify school‑home load.
Naturalisation typically after ~5 years of reckonable residence (with continuity requirements); dual citizenship allowed.
Low by EU standards; transparency relatively strong.
Parliamentary republic; PR‑STV voting; multiparty coalition governance common.

Our polyamory-positive household would find LGBTQ+ circles and meetup spaces in Dublin/Cork, but there’s still no legal recognition for multi-partner families and discretion helps with schools or immigration touchpoints.
Free preschool via ECCE (2 years, ~3 hrs/day, ~38 weeks). Full-day creches exist but waitlists/costs vary by city; NCS subsidies help.
Private/international schools in major cities; fees significant; admissions selective; secular options exist but capacity can be tight.
Significant liberal shifts (e.g., marriage equality, reproductive rights) alongside some conservative currents.
Focus on economy, services, housing; standard partisan frames.
Low systemic propaganda; normal political messaging.
Dublin’s buses, Luas, and DART make the core workable without a car, yet evening frequency and intercity links are thin enough that we’d still plan around a car for family errands.
Generally secular governance; residual church influence in education/health.
Hybrid common post‑pandemic; co‑working widely available.
Stamps (1/1G/4 etc.); CSEP can lead to Stamp 4 after a period; GEP longer path.
State Pension (Contributory) from about 66 with sufficient PRSI; occupational/private pillars common; EU portability good.
State pension based on PRSI contributions over years; consider private pensions; US‑Ireland totalization agreement may help—verify.
Eligibility depends on PRSI contributions and residence; private/occupational schemes portable; state benefits require contributions.
Niche demand concentrated in startups and some fintech/SaaS firms; roles appear irregularly and often expect polyglot skills.
Generally safe; petty crime in city cores; rare unrest episodes.
English‑medium public schools; many with Catholic patronage; limited international schools; Irish taught.
Roughly warmest Jul–Sep; otherwise chilly; wetsuits common.
Oceanic—cool summers, mild winters, frequent rain/overcast; long summer daylight, short winter days.
Generally moderate‑liberal; sex‑ed improving; verify local norms.
Robust anti‑discrimination; LGBTQ+ legal recognition; reproductive rights.
Typical daytime 8-15 C (46-59 F); frequent light rain; humidity moderate; longer daylight Mar-May.
High political and economic stability; protest risk low‑moderate.
Market‑friendly with social supports; strong MNC presence.
Open economy; corporate tax reforms ongoing per OECD.
Typical daytime 15-20 C (59-68 F); occasional 22-25 C (72-77 F); generally low to moderate humidity; cool evenings.
Processing times vary by route; expect weeks to months; fees apply.
Moderate; varies with housing/health outcomes.
More administrative/planning than overt; enforcement present.
.NET / Ruby / Game dev ranges; senior vs. mid; Dublin highest.
Saturdays for errands, sports, parks, day trips; many shops open Sunday with shorter hours; family pub lunches and local events common.
Primary school ~08:50-14:30; secondary ~09:00-16:00. Many office roles ~09:00-17:30; after-school care 14:30-18:00 common.
At least 4 weeks annually (plus public holidays).
Tech often 23–25+ days, varies by employer.
Positive toward EU partners; close but complex relationship with the UK.
Friendly, resilient, proud of heritage; outward-looking and pragmatic.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Often seen as friendly, welcoming, and culturally rich.
Critical Skills Employment Permit (CSEP), General Employment Permit (GEP), intra‑company transfer, student, family routes; Startup programmes via Enterprise Ireland.
Generally positive; high presence of US companies; straightforward processes.
Friendly, community‑oriented culture; vibrant music and pub life; strong literary/history scene.
Typical daytime 4-8 C (39-46 F); rare deep freezes; damp cold with occasional frost/sleet; snow uncommon outside uplands.
Legal max 48; typical around 39–40 in many sectors.
EU norms for leave and hours; team culture varies.
EU standards; unions present; termination processes regulated; non‑competes limited/enforceability varies.

Weather is generally predictable yet each season carries a couple of notable extremes that require monitoring and contingency planning. Seasonal Weather at 8.0/10 and Natural Disasters at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Noticeable winter darkness arrives but we can maintain energy with regular outdoor breaks and occasional light therapy. Seasonal Weather at 8.0/10 and Environment at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Two to three strong seasons offer great weather while shoulder months require occasional adjustments. Seasonal Weather at 8.0/10 and Environment at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for pleasant weather windows.
Basic needs are met but savings and extracurriculars are hard to sustain without extra support or side work.

Comfortable living is possible but major purchases or travel demand careful planning and occasional sacrifices. Typical Software Salaries at 8.0/10,0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.
Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated.0/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Only a handful of listings surface each year; expect bidding wars and significant trade-offs.0/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

We can find a few reputable co-living or cooperative projects though demand may require patience. Community Vibes at 8.0/10, Meetups & Communities at 8.0/10, and Family Life at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community living opportunities.

Locals are polite and willing to connect when we show initiative, though relationships build gradually. Community Vibes at 8.0/10, Meetups & Communities at 8.0/10, and Common Hobbies at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Generally welcoming yet periodic political rhetoric creates mild concern. Welcoming of US Migrants at 8.0/10, Progressivism at 8.0/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Mostly comfortable integration though some circles question motives or commitment to the country. Welcoming of US Migrants at 8.0/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 8.0/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.
Friendly exchanges happen when we initiate; staff and strangers respond positively. Community Vibes at 8.0/10,0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for surface interaction norms.

Relationships deepen steadily with consistent effort; vulnerability is appreciated though not automatic. Community Vibes at 8.0/10, Meetups & Communities at 8.0/10, and What Is Intriguing at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Most locals read body language well, though some settings skew closer than we prefer. Community Vibes at 8.0/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8.0/10, and View of self at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Openness is usually welcomed though some contexts expect diplomacy and softening of hard truths. Progressivism at 8.0/10, What Is Intriguing at 8.0/10, and Trust in Government at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.
Noticeable emphasis on grooming means we budget extra time and money to fit in.
We notice subtle comparisons; maintaining confidence requires occasional boundary setting.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for body image & fitness pressure.
Fashionable appearance is expected in many settings, adding planning time and costs.
Most encounters are considerate though occasional missteps require direct communication. Sex (Attitudes) at 8.0/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 8.0/10, and

Mostly flexible though some circles still expect traditional roles on first approach. Gender Roles at 8.0/10, Gender Fluidity at 8.0/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for gendered flirting expectations.
Acceptance varies—urban hubs are welcoming while suburbs expect discretion.0/10, and Community Vibes at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Most peers are nonjudgmental but traditional families may gossip. Sex (Attitudes) at 8.0/10, Nightlife & Music at 8.0/10, and Community Vibes at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Openness varies; we find understanding circles but remain discreet with institutions.0/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

Guns are present yet culturally treated as tools with strong safety expectations. Safety & Crime at 8.0/10, State Ideology at 8.0/10, and Political System at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Balanced approach: regulated markets exist alongside education and support. Progressivism at 8.0/10, Political System at 8.0/10, and Safety & Crime at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for controlled substance policies.

Most enforcement is targeted though occasional crackdowns create unease. Safety & Crime at 8.0/10, Progressivism at 8.0/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for drug enforcement climate.

Occasional events occur regionally, prompting situational awareness but not chronic fear. Safety & Crime at 8.0/10 and Stability at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for mass violence incidence.

Conditions are generally decent though some facilities lag in services or transparency. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8.0/10, Safety & Crime at 8.0/10, and Perceived Corruption at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Mental health burdens exist but are met with accessible services and open dialogue. Seasonal Weather at 8.0/10, Work-Life Balance at 8.0/10, and Community Vibes at 8.0/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depression prevalence.
